On Friday, January 24th, 26 OCHS students competed in the State We the People Competition at the University of Virginia. Mrs. Herndon’s Advanced Placement Government class divided into six teams/units and each group had to answer questions one and two of their unit. They were required to present their responses in front of a panel of three judges. Each response needed to be four minutes long.

After presenting their 4 minute response, they then had to answer questions from the judges for six minutes. These questions assessed their depth of knowledge about the Constitution, casework, historical and current events, laws, and civil liberties/freedoms.

OCHS students Arden Floyd, Alexis Lee, Emma Stewart, and Katie Webster received medals for their performance.

Every year OCHS Marketing students compete in a Shark Tank competition where they pitch their business/product idea to a panel of “sharks” for the opportunity to win scholarship or seed money for their business. Education First will drastically improve the quality of education for all of our clients, and we are excited to revolutionize the industry of education, by implementing new ways for students to learn and educators to educate.”

post_text: OCHS 9th grade Environmental Science students planted, tubed, and staked hundreds of canopy and understory trees to create a future riparian buffer along the Robinson River in Locust Dale, Virginia as part of the OCHS Meaning Watershed Educational Experience. As part of this project, students assessed the water quality of the Robinson River using PASCO probeware and iPads and conducted macroinvertebrate (tiny bug-like critters) sampling of the river to further assess river health. You may have seen Locust Grove Primary School’s “Anti-Bullying Tower” on display here and there around the district. It is presently at Locust Grove Middle School for its last stop this year after touring all of our schools and TEAC as well.

What is it?

Well…after collecting a large pile of styrofoam from furniture boxes and such, we at Locust Grove Primary School put together a large tower and painted it. Every student in the school got a chance to help paint. It was GREAT! Then we added white boards and post it notes with thoughts about “Anti-Bullying,” and asked viewers to add post its and draw on the white boards or add comments in our comment book as the tower toured all the schools in the district. We started an amazing dialog all around the schools about Bullying and how to deal with it…and hopefully eliminate it! It has been a big success and has traveled the district since early October, staying for various lengths of time at each stop. It’s been informative, interactive and a lot of fun!

post_text: On Sunday, March 17 a Dedication Ceremony was held for The Sizemore Fitness Center at Orange County High School (OCHS). School Board members were joined by former OCHS coaches and students as well as members of the community to celebrate the opening of the fitness center. The fitness center is named in memory of Paul M. Sizemore, who was a coach, teacher and athletic director at OCHS from 1952-1982. The vision for the fitness center began with School Board Member, Mrs. Judy Carter, who wanted the students at OCHS to have use of new cardio and strength training equipment. She worked with Mr. Bill Hager, an OCHS alumnus, to raise the funds for the equipment. Thanks to her dream and Mr. Hager’s efforts, and the generosity of the OCHS alumni and community members, over $55,000 was raised to purchase new equipment.

Students from Mr. Bryant, Ms. Haley, and Ms. Ford's classes at the Taylor Educational Administration Complex spent this summer and fall working to clean up the courtyard at TEAC to make it into a pollinator-friendly garden. With the guidance of Richard Jacobs from Culpeper Soil and Water Conservation District and help from Orange County Master Gardeners and TEAC staff, a butterfly-friendly rain garden was installed to reduce groundwater runoff and erosion and a pollinator garden was planted to provide a safe habitat for birds, bees, and butterflies.

This project was made possible by funding from the Chesapeake Bay Restoration Fund. For more information on the conservation efforts used in this courtyard, please visit www.culpeperswcd.org. For more information on the Chesapeake Bay Restoration Fund, please visit www.dmv.state.va.us.

ORANGE COUNTY SCHOOL BOARD DESIGNATED AS VSBA BOARD OF DISTINCTION

At an awards luncheon during last week’s Virginia School Boards Association (VSBA) Annual Convention, the Orange County School Board was designated as a VSBA Board of Distinction. Boards receiving this award must apply for it and meet specific requirements in four key areas: planning, policy, promotion, and board development. A panel of judges reviews the criteria submitted and determines those awarded the VSBA Board of Distinction status.

“The Orange County School Board is dedicated to improving the future by empowering our students to value learning, reach their full potential, and achieve their dreams”, said Sherrie Page, Orange County School Board chairman, “We are proud of Orange County Schools and the work that the School Board has accomplished, and we are honored to be a VSBA Board of Distinction.”

The board was recognized at the VSBA Annual Convention in Williamsburg, VA, which brings together school board members, superintendents, division administrators, and education officials from across the state.

post_text: Orange County School Board members Bette Winter, Carol Couch, Sherrie Page and Jim Hopkins (not pictured) attended the Legislative Advocacy Conference provided by the Virginia School Board Association on Sept 28, 2017 in Charlottesville, VA. Governor Terry McAuliffe was awarded the Virginia Legislative Award of Excellence by the Virginia School Board Association for his strong support of education during his 4 years as Governor of Virginia. According to the Governor, there are 68,000 cyber job openings In Virginia with a starting salary of $88,000 a year. In order to receive the needed computer credentials, less than a year of study after high school is required. Orange County School Board members proudly told Governor McAuliffe about the Hornet Tech Center at OCHS and the many computer credentials that are obtained by our students.

post_text: Dr. Brenda Tanner, Superintendent, attended the National Head Start Association's Fall Leadership Institute to serve as a panelist discussing partnerships between school divisions and Head Start. Other panelists included Scott Groginsky, National Head Start Association; Rolf Grafwallner, Council of Chief State School Officers, and Joanie Burke, Southeast Kansas Community Action Head Start. OCPS has a longstanding relationship with Head Start. An outreach program began in the 1973/74 school year with services provided on a traveling school bus that had been retrofitted as a classroom. Now, OCPS has over 200 students enrolled in early childhood programs, including those provided by Head Start.

On Tuesday, August 15 Orange County Public Schools welcomed 53 new teachers to the division.

New teachers received an overview of the division's instructional focus by Dr. John Almarode, professor at James Madison University. He presented information regarding effective instructional practices.

They also used teamwork and critical thinking to "break in" to OCPS using BreakoutEDI kits. For this, they solved puzzles and looked for clues using materials about Orange County and OCPS to unlock multiple locks on a locked box.

On Wednesday, August 16 they started the day with a bus tour of Orange County before dismissing to their respective schools.
